Probability

1. Probability basics


ID is: 4185 Seed is: 5006

Probabilities with more complex outcomes

What is the probability of rolling a number greater than 22 when you roll a standard six-sided die?

INSTRUCTIONS: Write your answer as a simplified fraction. Decimal answers will not be accepted.
Answer:

Probability of rolling a number greater than 22 ==

fraction
2 attempts remaining
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

How many ways can you get this favourable outcome? Which numbers on the die are greater than 22? So, how many ways are there of rolling a number greater than 22?

STEP: Use the probability formula
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

When you roll a standard die, there are 66 equally likely outcomes: one, two, three, four, five, and six. The favourable outcomes for rolling a number greater than 22 are shaded below.

P(greater than 2)=Number offavourable outcomesTotal number ofpossible outcomes=46=23P(greater than 2)=favourable outcomesNumber ofpossible outcomesTotal number of=46=23

Therefore, the probability of rolling a number greater than 22 is 2323.

ID is: 4177 Seed is: 8167

The probability scale

The diagram below shows the probability scale with an event, named AA, positioned on the scale.

Which of the following is a correct statement about Event AA?

Answer:
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

The probability scale runs from 00 to 11 and it is a measure of how likely an event is. Read the position of AA off the scale to get a measure of its probability. What do you think it means to have a probability of zero? What do you think it means to have a probability of 11?

STEP: Revise the probability scale
[−1 point ⇒ 1 / 2 points left]

The probability scale is a way of measuring how likely an event is.

  • Impossible events have a probability of 00. These are events that cannot happen.
  • Certain events have a probability of 11. These are events that will definitely happen.
  • All other events have a probability somewhere between 00 and 11, depending on how likely they are.

In this question, Event AA is placed at zero, meaning the event cannot happen. We say it is impossible.

An example: when you roll a standard die, "getting a 77" is impossible. There isn't a 77 on a standard die, so it cannot happen.

STEP: Interpret the position of AA on the scale
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

Therefore Event AA is impossible.

Submit your answer as:

The probability scale

The diagram below shows the probability scale with an event, named AA, positioned on the scale.

Which of the following is a correct statement about Event AA?

Answer:
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

The probability scale runs from 00 to 11 and it is a measure of how likely an event is. Read the position of AA off the scale to get a measure of its probability. What do you think it means to have a probability of zero? What do you think it means to have a probability of 11?

STEP: Revise the probability scale
[−1 point ⇒ 1 / 2 points left]

The probability scale is a way of measuring how likely an event is.

  • Impossible events have a probability of 00. These are events that cannot happen.
  • Certain events have a probability of 11. These are events that will definitely happen.
  • All other events have a probability somewhere between 00 and 11, depending on how likely they are.

In this question, AA is placed between the halfway point 1212 and the point 11, so there is a good chance it will happen and we say that it is likely

An example: if you have ten coins in your pocket (seven N=1N=1 coins and three N=5N=5 coins) then the probability of "getting a N=1N=1 is 70%70%. It is likely to happen."

STEP: Interpret the position of AA on the scale
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

Therefore Event AA is likely.

ID is: 4177 Seed is: 9046

The probability scale

The diagram below shows the probability scale with an event, named AA, positioned on the scale.

Which of the following is a correct statement about Event AA?

Answer:
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

The probability scale runs from 00 to 11 and it is a measure of how likely an event is. Read the position of AA off the scale to get a measure of its probability. What do you think it means to have a probability of zero? What do you think it means to have a probability of 11?

STEP: Revise the probability scale
[−1 point ⇒ 1 / 2 points left]

The probability scale is a way of measuring how likely an event is.

  • Impossible events have a probability of 00. These are events that cannot happen.
  • Certain events have a probability of 11. These are events that will definitely happen.
  • All other events have a probability somewhere between 00 and 11, depending on how likely they are.

In this question, AA is placed halfway along the line, meaning that the probability of Event AA happening is 50%50%.

An example: if you toss a coin, you have a fifty-fifty chance of "getting heads". P(getting heads)=50%=0.5=12P(getting heads)=50%=0.5=12.

STEP: Interpret the position of AA on the scale
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

Therefore P(A)=50%P(A)=50%.

ID is: 4191 Seed is: 298

Calculating probability as a percentage

  1. Emmanuel has a bag of 1010 coins. There are three N=1N=1 coins, two N=2N=2 coins, and five N=5N=5 coins. He picks one coin from the bag (without looking inside the bag). What is the probability of getting a N=5N=5 coin?

    INSTRUCTIONS:
    • Write your answer as a percentage. Remember that percent means per hundred. For example, 210=20100210=20100 which is 2020 per hundred =20%=20%.
    • The percentage symbol has already been given to you. You only need to type in the number.
    Answer:

    Probability of getting a N=5N=5 coin is %%.

    numeric
    2 attempts remaining
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

    How many ways can you get this favourable outcome? Which coins will correctly give you "getting a N=5N=5 coin"?

    STEP: Use the probability formula
    [−1 point ⇒ 1 / 2 points left]
    • There are 1010 coins inside the bag.
    • There are 55 favourable outcomes for getting a N=5N=5 coin.
    P(N=5 coin)=Number offavourable outcomesTotal number ofpossible outcomes=510P(N=5 coin)=favourable outcomesNumber ofpossible outcomesTotal number of=510
    STEP: Write the probability as a percentage
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

    The probability of getting N=5N=5 coin is:

    P(N=5)=510=510∖×100∖1%=50%P(N=5)=510=510∖×100∖1%=50%

    This means 5050 per hundred. Therefore the probability of getting N=5N=5 coin is 50%50%.

    Submit your answer as:

  2. Emmanuel puts the coin back into the bag. He then goes to a street market and wants to buy an orange which costs N=1.80N=1.80.

    If he randomly draws one coin from the bag, what is the probability that he will have enough to buy the orange?

    INSTRUCTIONS:
    • Write your answer as a percentage. Remember that percent means per hundred. For example, 210=20100210=20100 which is 2020 per hundred =20%=20%.
    • The percentage symbol has already been given to you. You only need to type in the number.
    Answer:

    Probability of having enough to buy an orange is %%

    numeric
    2 attempts remaining
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

    How many ways can you get this favourable outcome? Which coins will be enough to buy an orange?

    STEP: Use the probability formula
    [−1 point ⇒ 1 / 2 points left]
    • There are 1010 coins inside the bag.
    • There are 77 favourable outcomes that are enough to buy an orange.
    P(enough to buy an orange)=Number offavourable outcomesTotal number ofpossible outcomes=710P(enough to buy an orange)=favourable outcomesNumber ofpossible outcomesTotal number of=710
    STEP: Write the probability as a percentage
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

    The probability of having enough to buy an orange is:

    P(enough to buy an orange)=710=710∖×100∖1%=70%P(enough to buy an orange)=710=710∖×100∖1%=70%

    This means 7070 per hundred. Therefore the probability of having enough to buy an orange is 70%70%.

ID is: 4206 Seed is: 9860

Relative frequency and predictions

The image below shows a digital thermometer which measures body temperature in degrees Celcius (°C)(°C).

  1. The nurse at a medical clinic measures the body temperature of each child that visits the clinic. Here are the data recorded from the first 1010 children who visited the clinic yesterday:

    Body temperatures (°C°C)
    11 39.439.4 66 39.239.2
    22 39.039.0 77 39.439.4
    33 34.534.5 88 39.439.4
    44 36.936.9 99 36.336.3
    55 36.636.6 1010 36.136.1

    Here is a table used at the clinic for identifying health problems, such as hypothermia (too cold) or a fever (too hot).

    Diagnosis Body temperature
    Hypothermia Below 35°C35°C
    Normal 36°C−37°C36°C−37°C
    Fever Over 37.5°C37.5°C

    Calculate the relative frequency of children with a fever.

    Answer:

    The relative frequency of children with a fever is .

    numeric
    2 attempts remaining
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

    How many outcomes have temperatures recorded as a fever? How many trials were recorded in total?

    STEP: Use the formula for relative frequency
    [−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

    The relative frequency of a fever is:

    RF(fever)=frequencytotal numberof trialsRF(fever)=frequencyof trialstotal number
    NOTE: We will use the abbreviation RFRF for relative frequency, just as we use PP for probability.
    RF(fever)=510=0.5RF(fever)=510=0.5
    Submit your answer as:

  2. It is helpful to use past information to make predictions. If the nurse can predict roughly how many children come in to the clinic with a fever, this can help to plan how much medication the clinic needs.

    Over the month of September, the clinic saw 1,7531,753 children. The relative frequency of temperatures amongst children in September is below.

    Category of temperature Relative frequency
    Hypothermia 0.150.15
    Normal 0.60.6
    Fever 0.250.25

    In October, the clinic expects to see 2,0002,000 children. How many children can the clinic expect to have a normal temperature?

    Answer:

    The clinic can expect that children out of 2,0002,000 will have a normal temperature.

    numeric
    2 attempts remaining
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

    After 1,7531,753 patients, the relative frequency was 0.60.6. Use this relative frequency to make a prediction for how many children out of 2,0002,000 we expect will have a normal temperature.

    STEP: Make a prediction for 2,0002,000 children
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]
    To make a prediction, we multiply the relative frequency by the number of children.
    NOTE: We often use information from the past to make predictions about the future. But, this does not mean that we know what will happen. It is just the best guess, given the information that we have.
    • The relative frequency of a normal temperature is 0.60.6.
    • The prediction for 2,0002,000 children is 0.6×2000=12000.6×2000=1200.

    Therefore the clinic can expect that 1,2001,200 children out of 2,0002,000 will have a normal temperature.

    NOTE: Did you notice that the temperature categories listed in the table are not continuous? (One category does not start right after another category ends.) A temperature reading of 38.5°C38.5°C is a very clear result - this child has a fever! However, in reality some readings are trickier. A temperature of 37.3°C37.3°C could be normal, but it might also indicate a mild fever, so in that case a nurse would need more information to decide on the child's health.
    Submit your answer as:

    After 800800 patients, the relative frequency was 0.120.12. Use this relative frequency to make a prediction for how many children out of 1,0001,000 we expect will have a temperature that indicates hypothermia.

    STEP: Make a prediction for 1,0001,000 children
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]
    To make a prediction, we multiply the relative frequency by the number of children.
    NOTE: We often use information from the past to make predictions about the future. But, this does not mean that we know what will happen. It is just the best guess, given the information that we have.
    • The relative frequency of a temperature that indicates hypothermia is 0.120.12.
    • The prediction for 1,0001,000 children is 0.12×1000=1200.12×1000=120.

    Therefore the clinic can expect that 120120 children out of 1,0001,000 will have a temperature that indicates hypothermia.

    NOTE: Did you notice that the temperature categories listed in the table are not continuous? (One category does not start right after another category ends.) A temperature reading of 38.5°C38.5°C is a very clear result - this child has a fever! However, in reality some readings are trickier. A temperature of 37.3°C37.3°C could be normal, but it might also indicate a mild fever, so in that case a nurse would need more information to decide on the child's health.

Answer:

  2. The Ferrari will win the race:
  3. The cement mixer truck will win the race:
  4. A taxi will win the race:
2 attempts remaining
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 4 / 4 points left]

Think about how a race works, and think about who or what is actually racing.

STEP: What can happen in this race?
[−4 points ⇒ 0 / 4 points left]

It is possible that either the Ferrari or the cement mixer truck could win, but we know that the Ferrari is much faster than the cement mixer truck! The taxi cannot win since the taxi is not in this race. In a race, the first to finish is always the winner.

  1. Since we know how races work, it is certain that the winner will be the first to complete the race.
  2. Since a Ferrari is usually a lot faster than a cement mixer truck, it is likely that the Ferrari will win the race.
  3. Since a cement mixer truck is usually much slower than a Ferrari, it is unlikely that the cement mixer truck will win the race.
  4. Since a taxi is not in the race, it is impossible for the taxi to win the race.

Probability concepts

You pick a marble from a bag that contains one red marble and seven blue marbles.

How likely is it that you will get a primary coloured marble?

NOTE: The primary colours are red, blue, and yellow.
Answer: It is .
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

STEP: How likely is this to happen?
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

We can say the following about the likelihood:

  • You will always get a primary coloured marble. All of the marbles are a primary colour so this is certain (this will definitely happen).
  • There are seven blue marbles and only one red marble. Therefore it is likely that you will get a blue marble and unlikely that you will get a red marble.
  • There are no green marbles, therefore it is impossible to get a green marble (this cannot happen).

Consider the event below and decide the likelihood of the event occuring.

A summer's day is cold.

HINT: <no title>

You must think about how often this event usually occurs. Remember that:

  • impossible events never happen.
  • unlikely events usually don't happen, except on rare occassions.
  • equally likely events occur as often as not: there is a 50/5050/50 chance.
  • likely events usually happen, although not always.
  • certain events always happen.

  • likely events usually happen, although not always.
  • certain events always happen.

NOTE: This does not mean that it is impossible to be cold in summer. It just means that this is not what happens most of the time.

3. Practical applications


ID is: 4195 Seed is: 3813

Understanding relative frequency

Hein tossed a coin 99 times and recorded the outcomes of this experiment in the tally table below.

Side of coin Tally marks
Heads
Tails
Answer:

The of getting heads is 5959.

HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]
  • Frequency is the number of times that an outcome occurs in an experiment.
  • The relative frequency of an outcome in an experiment is found by dividing the frequency of that outcome by the total number of times that the experiment was conducted.
  • The probability of an event is found by dividing the number of favourable outcomes by the total possible outcomes. It does not depend on the outcome of a particular experiment.
STEP: Choose the correct description
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

The probability of getting heads when we toss a coin is always 1212.

But, when we toss a coin in an experiment, we will not necessarily get heads half of the time. Events in the real world do not always work out as we might expect.

In this experiment, Hein got heads 55 times. This is called frequency.

If we take this frequency and divide it by the total number of times the experiment was conducted, we get relative frequency. In this experiment, the relative frequency of getting heads is 5959.

NOTE: Relative frequency does not have to be the same as probability.

5959 is the number of times that heads occured in the experiment, divided by the total number of times that the experiment was conducted.

So, the relative frequency of getting heads is 5959.

TIP: Tally marks are a way of keeping track of the number of times that each outcome has occurred. Each time that Hein gets a heads, he will draw a line (called a tally mark). When he gets the fifth heads, he crosses out the four marks. So four crossed out lines actually means five heads.
Submit your answer as:

The probability that your opponent might get a picture card from your hand is .

P=Number of favourable outcomesTotal number of possible outcomesP=favourable outcomesNumber of possible outcomesTotal number of 

We need to determine:

  1. the number of favourable outcomes; and
  2. the total number of possible outcomes.

P=Number of favourable outcomesTotal number of possible outcomes=710P=favourable outcomesNumber of possible outcomesTotal number of =710

The probability that your opponent might get a picture card from your hand is 710710.

    Answer:

    Which one of the following statements about this comparison is correct?

    2 attempts remaining
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 3 / 3 points left]

    Compare the relative frequency and probability. Are they the same or different? Will this always be the case?

    STEP: Compare the relative frequency and probability
    [−2 points ⇒ 1 / 3 points left]

    We have already worked out the following relative frequency and probability of rolling a one:

    • Probability =0.17=0.17
    • Relative frequency =0.17=0.17

    The relative frequency is a measure of what actually happened in an experiment. We expect this to be close to the probability of that outcome, especially when we do many trials. But, this does not always happen. What happens in the real world is not always what we expect to happen.

    The relative frequency of rolling a one in this experiment happens to be exactly equal to the probability of rolling a one! But they did not have to be equal.

    STEP: Choose the correct option about this comparision
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 3 points left]
    A ✘ The relative frequency of an outcome in an experiment must always be equal to the probability of that outcome.
    The relative frequency of an outcome can be equal to the probability of that outcome, but it is often different.
    B ✔ The relative frequency of an outcome in an experiment does not have to be equal to the probability of that outcome.
    This statement is true.
    C ✘ The relative frequency of an outcome in an experiment is never equal to the probability of that outcome.
    The relative frequency of an outcome is often different to the probability of that outcome, but it can be the same.
    D ✘ In an experiment, the relative frequency of an outcome should be equal to the probability of that outcome.
    As we repeat experiments more times, we expect the relative frequency of an outcome to get closer to the probability of that outcome. But, this does not mean that the two should be equal.

Theoretical probability

A student finds a 6 sided die and then rolls the die once on a table. What is the probability that the die lands on either 3 or 6?

INSTRUCTION: Write your answer as a decimal (correct to 2 decimal places).
Answer: The probability is .
numeric
2 attempts remaining
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

You must use the formula for probability:

P(E)=n(E)n(S)P(E)=n(E)n(S)
STEP: Use the formula for theoretical probability
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

To calculate probability, we first recall the formula:

P(E)=n(E)n(S)P(E)=n(E)n(S)

Secondly we identify the values for the situation described in the question:

n(E)=number of outcomes in the event set=2n(S)=number of possible outcomes in the sample space=6n(E)=number of outcomes in the event set=2n(S)=number of possible outcomes in the sample space=6

Finally, we substitute into the formula and work out the answer.

P(E)=n(E)n(S)=26P(E)≈0.3333P(E)=n(E)n(S)=26P(E)≈0.3333

Remember that the question says your answer should be "correct to 2 decimal places," which means rounding to two places. Therefore, the probability that the die lands on either 3 or 6 ≈0.33≈0.33.

Simple calculations with relative frequency

Musa and Kosma love playing Mancala. Mancala is a two-player game using tokens such as stones, marbles, or beans. The tokens are placed in rows of sections carved out of wood or drawn into sand.

The aim of the game is to cleverly move all your tokens to your "Mancala", the big section at the end, before your opponent.

Here are the game scores from yesterday:

Musa won Kosma won

Answer the following questions:

INSTRUCTION: Do not round off decimal answers.
Answer:
  1. The relative frequency of Kosma winning is .
  2. Complete: (relative frequency of Musa winning) + (relative frequency of Kosma winning) is .
  3. The sum of all the relative frequencies equals 11.
numeric
one-of
type(string)
2 attempts remaining
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 3 / 3 points left]

Use the formula for the relative frequency of an event:

RF=number of timesthe event occurredtotal number oftrials conductedRF=the event occurrednumber of timestrials conductedtotal number of
STEP: Calculate the relative frequency of the event "Kosma wins"
[−1 point ⇒ 2 / 3 points left]
NOTE: In order to make the solution easier to read, we will use the abbreviation RFRF for Relative Frequency, just as we use PP for Probability.
RF=number of timesthe event occurredtotal number oftrials conductedRF=the event occurrednumber of timestrials conductedtotal number of

From the table, we find:

  • the frequency of Kosma winning is 1212
  • the total number of trials is 8+128+12
RF(Kosma wins)=1220=0.6RF(Kosma wins)=1220=0.6
STEP: Add the relative frequencies
[−1 point ⇒ 1 / 3 points left]
RF(Musa wins)=0.4RF(Kosma wins)=0.6RF(Musa wins)=0.4RF(Kosma wins)=0.6
∴RF(Musa wins)+RF(Kosma wins)=0.4+0.6=1∴RF(Musa wins)+RF(Kosma wins)=0.4+0.6=1
STEP: What do you know about the sum of all the relative frequencies?
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 3 points left]
RF=number of timesthe event occurredtotal number oftrials conductedRF=the event occurrednumber of timestrials conductedtotal number of

The sum of the frequencies of all the possible outcomes is equal to the total number of trials.

Therefore, the sum of the relative frequencies:

=sum of allthe frequenciestotal numberof trials=total numberof trialstotal numberof trials=1=the frequenciessum of allof trialstotal number=of trialstotal numberof trialstotal number=1

The sum of all the relative frequencies always equals 11.

Relative frequency and probability graphed

Hafsah tosses a coin 1010 times. She draws two graphs based on the results of this experiment, shown below:

One graph shows the relative frequency of getting heads after each toss. The other shows the probability of getting heads on a single coin toss.

  1. Select the correct answer to complete the following:

    Answer:

    The line ff represents the of getting heads. As we increase the number of we expect the relative frequency to get closer to the probability.

    2 attempts remaining
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

    One is a line graph and one is a broken-line graph. Why is this?

    What is the difference between relative frequency and probability?

    STEP: Which line on the graph is showing probability and which is showing relative frequency?
    [−1 point ⇒ 1 / 2 points left]
    The probability of getting heads on a single toss is always 1212 since one out of the two faces on a coin is heads. The likelihood or probability stays the same - it does not matter how many times you toss the coin.
    The relative frequency of getting heads is calculated as the number of times you got heads, divided by the number of times you tossed the coin. The relative frequency changes depending on what happened and how many times you tossed the coin.

    We can see the output of Graph ff stays the same. Graph ff is a horizontal line graph showing a constant output of 1212 which is shown as the decimal 0.50.5. The output does not change with the number of coin tosses. So, Graph ff shows the probability.

    The line ff represents the probability of getting heads.

    STEP: Look at what happens as the coin is tossed more times
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]
    A trend is a general direction in which something is developing or changing.

    Just like pages in a book, we read graphs from left to right. As more coins are tossed (look from zero tosses to ten tosses) we can see a trend. At first we can see the relative frequency can be quite different from the probability. But as we toss more coins, we can expect the relative frequency to get closer to the probability.

    The graphs show that:

    • relative frequency is not always equal to probability.
    • we can expect the relative frequency to get closer to probability as we toss the coin more times.

    As we increase the number of coin tosses we expect the relative frequency to get closer to the probability.

    Submit your answer as: and

  2. Use the graph to determine whether the outcome of the first coin toss in the experiment was heads or tails.

    Answer:

    The outcome of the first coin toss was:

    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

    What does the graph show for the relative frequency after one toss?

    STEP: Look at the relative frequency value on Graph gg after one toss
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

    The coordinate (1,0)(1,0) is on Graph gg. This means after one toss, the relative frequency of getting heads was 00.

    RF=numberof headstotal numberof tosses0=numberof heads1∴number of heads=0RF=of headsnumberof tossestotal number0=of headsnumber1∴number of heads=0

    The outcome of the first coin toss was tails.

Relative frequency and tallies

Daniel and Qiniso love playing Mancala. Mancala is a two-player game using tokens such as stones, marbles, or beans. The tokens are placed in rows of sections carved out of wood or drawn into sand.

The aim of the game is to cleverly move all your tokens to your "Mancala", the big section at the end, before your opponent.

Here are the game scores from yesterday:

Daniel won Qiniso won

  1. How many possible outcomes are there for one game?

    NOTE: In this version of Mancala, there is one winner. The outcome cannot be a draw.
    Answer:

    There are possible outcomes for this game of Mancala.

    numeric
    2 attempts remaining
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

    How many outcomes can happen when the game is played?

    STEP: Think about the possible outcomes
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

    For a single game of Mancala, there are 22 possible outcomes:

    1. Daniel will win and Qiniso will lose.
    2. Qiniso will win and Daniel will lose.

    There are 22 possible outcomes for this Mancala game.

    Submit your answer as:

    Answer:

    The frequency of Daniel winning is .

    numeric
    2 attempts remaining
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

    The frequency of Daniel winning is the number of times that he won.

    STEP: How many times did Daniel win?
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

    The number of times each outcome happens is called the frequency.

    You can see in the tally table that Daniel won 66 times.

    NOTE: Tally marks are used for counting scores in groups of 55. Each stick, or tally marking, means 11 score, so |=1|=1 and |||=3|||=3. After four tally markings, a diagonal line is drawn to show a group of 55.

    The frequency of Daniel winning is 66.

    Submit your answer as:

  3. How many times did Daniel and Qiniso play Mancala yesterday?

    Answer:

    Daniel and Qiniso played Mancala times yesterday.

    numeric
    2 attempts remaining

    [−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

    The frequency of Daniel winning is 66, and the frequency of Qiniso winning is 1010. How many games were played in total?

    STEP: How many games were played in total?
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

    To calculate the total number of trials conducted in this experiment, we remember:

    • A game of Mancala has only two possible outcomes.
    • Daniel won 66 times.
    • Qiniso won 1010 times.

    So they must have played 6+10=166+10=16 times in total.

    • A game of Mancala has only two possible outcomes.
    • Songezo won 55 times.
    • Saymore won 1111 times.

    So they must have played 5+11=165+11=16 times in total.

Relative frequency and probability terminology

Select the correct word or statement from the list to complete the sentence below.

Answer:

The of an event is the number of times that event occurs during experimental trials, divided by the number of trials conducted.

HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

You may find it helpful to revise the terms probability, relative frequency, theoretical probability, experimental probability, outcome, event, likelihood, experiment, and trial.

STEP: Recall the definition of relative frequency
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]
The term relative frequency is also known as the experimental probability. The relative frequency of an event is the number of times that event occurs during experimental trials, divided by the total number of trials conducted.

Therefore the relative frequency of an event is the number of times that event occurs during experimental trials, divided by the number of trials conducted.

[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

Therefore a prediction is a statement of what you think will happen in the future.

Relative frequency and probability terminology

Select the correct word or statement from the list to complete the sentence below.

Answer:

The result of a trial in an experiment is called the .

HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

You may find it helpful to revise the terms probability, relative frequency, theoretical probability, experimental probability, outcome, event, likelihood, experiment, and trial.

STEP: Recall what you know about probability experiments
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]
In an experiment, a trial is the procedure that takes place to test the experiment. A result of a trial is called an outcome, and the specific outcome (or set of outcomes) is known as an event.

Therefore the result of a trial in an experiment is called the outcome.

Coin experiment

Bonani tosses a fair coin 230230 times.

  1. How many times would Bonani expect to get heads in this experiment?

    Answer:

    Bonani would expect to get heads times.

    numeric
    2 attempts remaining
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

    What is the probability of getting heads on a single coin toss?

    STEP: Use the probability to determinet the expected number of outcomes
    [−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

    When you toss a coin, you can either get heads or tails, and both are equally likely. So, the probability of getting heads on a fair coin is 1212.

    If we toss a coin 230230 times, we expect half of those to be heads. So we expect to get

    12×230=115 heads12×230=115 heads
    NOTE: Just because we expect to get 115115 heads does not mean that this will actually happen. This is just our best estimate.
    Submit your answer as:

  2. Bonani now does the experiment. He does not get heads once.

    How likely is this outcome?

    Answer: This outcome is .
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

    How does this outcome compare with what was expected?

    STEP: Evaluate the likelihood
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

    Just because we expect 115115 heads, this does not mean that 115115 heads will definitely happen when the coin is tossed 230230 times. Experiments can produce outcomes that we do not expect, like this one did.

    Bonani did not get heads once, which means that he got 00 heads in 230230 coin tosses. This is very unlikely! But, it is still possible. So, the best choice from the options is unlikely.

Probability formula

What is the probability of selecting a circle from the shapes below?

INSTRUCTION: Write the probability as a simplified fraction. Decimal answers will not be accepted.
Answer: The probability of selecting a circle is .
fraction
2 attempts remaining
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

Use the probability formula:

P=Number of favourable outcomesTotal number of possible outcomesP=favourable outcomesNumber of possible outcomesTotal number of 
STEP: Use the probability formula to answer the question
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

We need to determine the probability of selecting a circle from a group of 88 shapes. We need to use the probability formula to answer this question. The probability, PP, of an event is:

P=Number of favourable outcomesTotal number of possible outcomesP=favourable outcomesNumber of possible outcomesTotal number of 
  • We are asked the probability of selecting a circle.
  • Favourable outcomes: there are 88 circles.
  • Possible outcomes: there are 88 shapes shown in total.
P=Number of favourable outcomesTotal number of possible outcomes=88P=favourable outcomesNumber of possible outcomesTotal number of =88

The probability of selecting a circle is 11.
